Graphical abstract The sintering process on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts in the heterogeneous liquid phase assisted methanol synthesis from CO2/H2 was investigated. In order to better understand the sintering event, in addition to standard methods (XRD, XPS, BET, ICP-OES) microscopic techniques with different magnifications such as SEM-EDX, AFM, and TEM were used. Water has been identified as the sintering agent. In addition to eliminating water with CO, another way was found to remove water from the catalyst surface and therefore to counteract the sintering during catalysis. This goal can be achieved by using highly polar solvents allowing to synthesize MeOH solely from carbon dioxide and hydrogen, without deactivating the catalyst or using carbon monoxide. Keywords Methanol synthesis Liquid phase catalysis Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 Sintering mechanism Counteract deactivation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methanol is one of the most important basic chemicals. It is industrially obtained using a heterogeneous gas phase reaction on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts. In this process, syngas with an addition of CO2 is used as reactant. It is synthesized according to the reactions ( 1 ) and ( 2 ).[1–3] (1) CO 2 + 3 H 2 ⇌ CH 3 O H + H 2 O (2) CO + 2 H 2 ⇌ CH 3 O H Of particular interest in methanol synthesis is the kinetic preference of CO2 over CO as the reactant by the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst.[1,2] This aspect is especially motivating in terms of counteracting the anthropogenic climate change. Emitted CO2 can be captured and afterwards usefully processed into a highly required industrial chemical compound such as MeOH. Therefore, attempts are being made to operate the process without carbon monoxide and with green hydrogen. However, lower activities (compared to the syngas process) and catalyst deactivation make methanol synthesis from carbon dioxide and hydrogen alone less economically viable.[4–6] Direct methanol synthesis in the capture agents has been tested for several decades.[7] This technology is intended to combine the capture of CO2 from flue gas with direct utilization as a reactant for methanol synthesis, and is therefore part of the Carbon Capture and Utilization (CCU) attempt. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts acting in the capture reagents are studied.[8] The heterogeneous model relies mainly on the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, which is already established in the gas phase synthesis. Benefits of introducing an additional liquid phase shall be the avoidance of hot spots on the solid-state catalyst, absence of the need to desorb the carbon dioxide from the solvent for further use and an additional catalytic effect of the solvent (for example activation of the CO2 by the formation of a chemical bond with the capture agent).[7,9–11] A wide variety of different solvents have already been tested, including alcohols[12–25], amines[13,14,18,26–29], mineral oils[30–32], alkanes[33], ethers[14,34,35] and mixtures of these liquids[13,18]. Syngas is used for methanol catalysis in most of these studies. When using CO2 as the sole carbon source in the liquid phase methanol catalysis, a sintering of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3-catalyst has been reported by Kothandaraman et al. [13] (increasing the mean crystal size of copper from 21 nm to 40 nm), but neither causes nor consequences were investigated any further. In this work, however, a systematic overview of the influence of the different solvents on the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst during CO2/H2 methanol synthesis is carried out. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Argon (Ar, Nippon, 99.999 %), hydrogen (H2, Nippon, 99.999 %), carbon monoxide (CO, Air Liquide, 99.997 %), carbon dioxide (CO2, Nippon, 99.995 %), nitrous oxide (N2O, Praxair, 99.995 %), copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2 · 3 H2O, abcr, 99.5 %), zinc(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2 · 6 H2O, abcr, 98 %), aluminum(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3 · 9H2O, Carl Roth, 98 %), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, abcr, 99 %), diethylmethylamine (C5H13N, Sigma Aldrich, 97 %), diethylamine (C4H11N, Alfa Aesar, 99 %), methanol (CH4O, Carl Roth, 99.9 %), tripropylamine (C9H21N, abcr, 98 %), tributylamine (C12H27N, abcr, 98 %), diethylethanolamine (C6H15NO, Acros Organics, 99 %), ethanol (C2H6O, Sigma Aldrich, 99.8 %), propan-1-ol (C3H8O, Fluka, 99.8 %), butan-1-ol (C5H10O, AppliChem Biochemica, 99 %), hexan-1-ol (C6H14O, Honeywell, 98 %), nonan-1-ol (C9H20O, Merck, 98 %), n-nonane (C9H20, Fluka, 99 %), polyethylene glycol 400 (C800H1602O401, Carl Roth, 98 %), triethylene glycol dimethyl ether (C8H18O4, Sigma Aldrich, 99 %), acetonitrile (C2H3N, Analar Normapur, 99.5 %), ethylene glycol (C2H6O2, VEB Laborchemie Apolda, pure, GC–MS analysis has shown no contamination), and 1,2-propylene carbonate (C4H6O3, Sigma Aldrich, 99.7 %) were used without further purification. Triethylamine (C6H15N, Alfa Aesar, 99 %) was dried by boiling 250 mL of the solvent with 2 g CaH2 and 0.2 g LiAlH4. Iron phthalocyanine was used as an indicator. The dry solvent was then purified by distillation and stored in a dry argon atmosphere (glove box, MBraun, H2O and O2 < 0.1 ppm). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The catalyst was prepared by adding a 100 mL solution consisting of the dissolved metal nitrates (0.1 M, atomic ratio 6:3:1 for Cu:Zn:Al) to 400 mL of distilled water (addition speed: 1.6 mL/min). The mixture was stirred and maintained at 65 °C. To keep the pH constant at 6.8, a 0.16 M sodium carbonate solution was pumped in accordingly. After complete addition of the metal nitrate solution, the suspension was stirred at 65 °C for 1 h. The precursor was then separated from the supernatant, washed withsixliters of distilled water sodium-free and dried at 110 °C for 20 h. The precursor was heated in a muffle furnace (Nabertherm, P330) to 330 °C (heating rate 2 K/min) and calcined in air at that temperature for 4 h. Afterwards, the catalyst was activated at 260 °C in argon hydrogen mixture flow (100 mL/min, 95 vol% Ar, 5 vol%H2) for 4 h (heating rate from room temperature 2 K/min). The catalyst was then stored in an argon purged glove box. 2.3 Characterization techniques 2.3.1 ICP-OES The reduced catalysts (approximately 30 mg) were dissolved in 5 mL conc. nitric acid. The solution was then diluted 200 times with distilled water. An ICP-OES apparatus (iCAP 6500, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was then used to determine the composition in terms of the copper, zinc, aluminum and sodium content. 2.3.2 X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) XRPD patterns were recorded on a BRUKER D2 Phaser X-ray diffractometer with a Lynxeye detector (Cu Kα1 radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å). The X-ray tube is operated at 30 kV and 10 mA. Measurements were performed with a step size of 0.02° and 2 s dwell time. Reference diffractograms were taken from the ICSD.[36] The mean crystal sizes L of copper ( Fm 3 ¯ m ) and zinc oxide ( P 6 3 m c ) were determined according to Scherrer‘s equation ( 3 ),[37] (3) L = K ∙ λ Δ ( 2 θ ) ∙ c o s θ where K is the shape factor (typically 0.89), λ the X-ray wavelength (1.5406 Å), Δ ( 2 θ ) the line broadening at half the maximum intensity (in radians and corrected for the instrumental line broadening 0.0421°) and θ the Bragg angle. 2.3.3 Nitrogen cryoadsorption using the BET method The measurements of the specific surface areas were carried out by nitrogen cryoadsorption using the BELSORPmini II (BEL JAPAN, INC.) apparatus. Prior to the measurements, the samples were dried in vacuum at 150 °C for six hours. The results are given in Table 1 (averaged over three measurements). 2.3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS measurements were carried out in a spectrometer from Specs equipped with the Phoibos 150 analyzer and a 2D CMOS detector. The reduced samples were prepared and transferred under inert conditions. For excitation, a monochromatic X-ray tube (XR50) equipped with an aluminum anode (1486.71 eV) was used. The spectra were measured with a pass energy of 15 eV. The charging was compensated using a flood gun. Fitting procedures for data evaluation were carried out with the CasaXPS software. Carbon was not considered due to adventitious carbon. 2.3.5 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) experiments were carried out in an analytical high-resolution (HR) transmission electron microscope JEM-2200FS from JEOL Ltd. that was equipped with a field emission gun operating at 200 kV, an ultra-high resolution objective lens (Cs = 0.5 mm), an in-column energy-filter (Ω-filter), and a CESCOR probe aberration corrector (CEOS GmbH). A highly sensitive 2 K × 2 K CCD camera (Gatan, Inc., USA) was used for recording bright field TEM images, HRTEM micrographs, selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns, and electron energy loss spectra (EELS). The analysis and data evaluation were performed with the program Digital Micrograph (Gatan). 2.3.6 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) SEM measurements were conducted on a JEOL JSM-7001F with an accelerating voltage of 5 kV. The distribution of Cu and Zn was investigated with EDX (Quantax, Bruker, accelerating voltage 15 kV). The samples were previously coated with carbon to ensure electrical conductivity. 2.3.7 Atomic force microscopy The topography was measured in non-contact mode (NCM), using a Park NX10 atomic force microscope. Imaging was performed utilizing 160AC-NA cantilevers. The powder samples were pressed into tablets. 2.3.8 Dissociative N2O adsorption Metallic copper can be selectively oxidized at the surface with nitrous oxide to Cu2O.[38,39] The mass increase during this reaction was followed gravimetrically using a Sensys TG-DSC (SETARAM). The reduced catalysts were transferred under inert conditions. Oxidation was carried out at 70 °C in an N2O/Ar stream (5/95 vol%). The mass increase was then used to calculate the amount of Cu on the surface. 2.4 Catalytic measurement The catalytic measurements were carried out in a self-built stainless-steel reactor. Volume and setup of the reactor are given in the Supplementary Material (Fig. S1). The reactor was filled in a glove box (MBraun) with 300 mg of the reduced catalyst, 10 mL of solvent, and a magnetic stirrer (PTFE). The reactor was sealed and then heated to 170 °C (stirring speed 400 rpm). After reaching the constant temperature, the reaction was started by applying 20 bar of CO or CO2 and 75 bar of H2. The reaction was terminated by rapid cooling of the reactor in an ice bath. Once the reactor was cold, the catalyst was inertly filtered from the supernatant. The solution was analyzed quantitatively (averaged over three measurements) with a GC-FID (HP 5890 Series II, Headspace Sampler: HP 7694, Column: HP-1) and qualitatively with a GC–MS (HP 6890, Column: HP-5MS UI). The catalyst was first dried in an argon stream for one hour and then in vacuum for two hours at room temperature. Afterwards, the used catalyst was stored in a glove box. The different solvents with their structural formulas and abbreviations are given in Fig. 1 . For the gas phase experiment in Fig. 9, a similar preparation was used with 200 mg of the reduced catalyst and smaller amounts of solvent (corresponding to a concentration of 22.5 mM for TEA, EtOH and ethylene glycol and 7.5 mM for propylene carbonate). CO2 and H2 (1:3) were added after reaching 200 °C, so that the equilibrium pressure will be 50 bar. The reaction was terminated after 11 d. The catalyst was inertly suspended in dry TEA and then separated from the supernatant. The catalysts were dried as described above. 2.5 Theoretical calculation of the dipole moments Conformational search for each solvent molecule was performed using metadynamics as provided by the program crest[40,41] using the GFN2-xTB hamiltonian[42]. The dipole moment was calculated for the most stable structure at GFN2-xTB level using RI-MP2[43,44], RI-DSD-PBEPBE[45,46] and RI-DSD-PBEP86[45,46] utilizing the def2-QZVPP[47] basis set and the auxiliary basis sets def2/J for the RICOSX[48,49] approach to speed up the coulomb and exchange integrals and the def2-QZVPP/C[50] to speed up the RI-MP2 integral transformation. The dipole moment was obtained from the relaxed electron densities treated at MP2 level or double hybrid level (I). All calculations were performed using the program orca 5.0.2[51]. Since the minimum structures at GFN2-xTB level do not necessarily coincide with the minimum structure at higher level, the most stable structure at the higher level has to be considered as well. As the conformational search results in thousands of conformations for some solvent molecules, a filter approach as implemented in the program curcuma was applied. All conformations that differ by a RMSD of 0.9 A were identified as different and accepted for subsequent dipole calculation. The complete list of the number of structures obtained from conformational search as well as the number of finally accepted and rejected structures are given in the Supplementary Material (Table S6). The subsequent single point calculation on all accepted structures were performed using RI-MP2, RI-DSD-PBEPBE, and RI-DSD-PBE86 with relaxed electron densities. The final dipole moment was taken from the most stable solvent conformation at each higher level of theory (II). In general, the calculated dipole moments for approach II are in better agreement with the experimental values. However, the dipole moment of Triglyme is estimated worse using II compared to I. Therefore, the calculated dipole moments from II are taken for further evaluation for all solvents, with the exception of Triglyme, where the values from I are used (Table 2 ). Further information on the determination of these dipole moments is provided in the Supplementary Material. 2.6 Absorption measurements Solubility measurements of CO2 and H2 in selected solvents at 170 °C were performed in a setup similar to [59,60]. 40 mL of the solvent was added inertly to a reactor with Teflon inlet, pressure and temperature sensor (Vreactor = 101.69 mL). After the temperature was constant, gas was gradually introduced to the reactor from a reservoir (Vreservoir = 225.41 mL), which was also equipped with a temperature and pressure sensor. The liquid volumes of the solvents at the reaction temperature were obtained using the densities, vapor pressures, and van der Waals coefficients (calculated from critical temperature and pressure) reported in [61–70]. Lemmon's equation[71] was used to determine the H2 amounts. CO2 amounts were obtained using densities from the NIST database[72]. The amount of absorbed gas was calculated as the difference between the amount added from the reservoir and the amount still present in the gas phase of the reactor. According to Henry's law, the Henry constants H i c p were calculated from the concentration of the gas in the solvent at different equilibrium gas pressures. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Property changes during catalysis leading to deactivation of the catalyst in triethylamine (TEA) During the synthesis of methanol in tertiary amines (TXA), two side reactions take place. First the amine decomposition ( 4 ) occurs. The TXA reacts with water to form the secondary amine (DXA) and an alcohol (XOH). In reaction ( 5 ), the subsequent methanol removal reaction is stated. The formed methanol is converted with the secondary amine to another tertiary amine (DXMA). Side reactions that consume methanol are only observed with amines (compared to the solvents in Fig. 1). In reaction ( 5 ), the water, which initially reacted in the amine decomposition ( 4 ), is recovered. Therefore, these reactions appear to be water catalyzed. (4) TXA + H 2 O ⇌ D X A + X O H (5) DXA + M e O H ⇌ D X M A + H 2 O In order to estimate the activity of the catalyst at a given time of the reaction, the total amount of methanol ever formed in the experiment reflected by the sum of MeOH and DXMA was determined (Fig. 2 ). In the following, the sum of the amounts of MeOH and DXMA is denoted as nMeOH+DXMA, where X in DXMA represents the alkyl group of the solvent (e.g., in triethylamine, X is equivalent to an ethyl group). As the reaction time increases, the production rate decreases. To verify that the decrease in the production rate is not simply due to thermodynamic limitation (equilibrium of reaction ( 1 )), reaction ( 5 ) is used. In this attempt (Fig. 2), the solvent consisted of 10 vol% diethylamine (DEA) and 90 vol% TEA and therefore the formed MeOH was almost completely converted to diethylmethylamine (DEMA). The nMeOH+DXMA formed in the TEA/DEA mixture is approximately halved compared to the pure TEA experiment (TEA/DEA: 3.6 mmol/gCat, MeOH:DEMA = 3:100 and TEA: 6.9 mmol/gCat, MeOH:DEMA = 1:3). The explanation for this behavior is provided in section 3.3. However, it can be stated that, despite the removal of methanol, no increase in the production rate occurred. Therefore, no thermodynamic limitation can be present and it is likely that a deactivation of the catalyst takes place. To investigate this deactivation, the dried catalysts were examined (Fig. 3 ). Both copper and zinc oxide sinter during the CO2/H2 catalysis to methanol, resulting in a sixfold increase in the mean crystal size after 96 h for ZnO and a doubling in the case of Cu. Rapid sintering, especially at the beginning of the reaction, is expected since the nanoparticles have much greater mobility than larger crystals formed by the sintering process itself.[73] According to the increase of the mean crystal size, the specific surface area (Table 1) and the amount of copper on the surface (Supplementary Material, Table 1) of the catalyst also decreases with progressing reaction time. Also, deactivation due to leaching did not occur during the catalysis, which could have become an issue especially when using an additional liquid phase (Supplementary Material, Fig. S3). Another aspect of the sintering may be the decrease of copper and zinc oxide on the surface (Supplementary Material, Fig. S2). It appears that the oxygen-rich aluminum species on the surface increases as the reaction time progresses. Alumina is only added as a structural promoter, but has no catalytic activity by itself.[74–77] The catalytic activity of copper based catalysts is usually determined by the surface area of this component and therefore, an accumulation of alumina on the surface also leads to a deactivation of the catalyst.[39,78]. The decrease in catalytically active copper and zinc oxide surface area due to sintering of these two species may be the reason for the decrease in catalytic activity. This phenomenon was also observed in the gas phase methanol catalysis, but not as drastic and fast as presented in this study.[4,79,80] To better understand the property changes of the catalysts, microscopic techniques with different magnifications were used (Fig. 4 and Fig. 5). 3.2 Microscopic techniques to compare the catalyst before and after CO2/H2 methanol synthesis The catalyst before the methanol synthesis is well dispersed and homogeneous (Fig. 4 , a and c). Copper and zinc oxide are present next to each other, which guarantees good catalytic activity.[81–83] The particles are small and also possess the typical spherical structure of copper nanoparticles (see Fig. 4e). On the other hand, the catalyst after 96 h shows big agglomerates (Fig. 4, b and f). This behavior matches the BET results already presented (Table 1). The agglomeration of the particles results in the loss of specific surface area and therefore also in catalytic activity of the catalyst. The underlying reason for this aggregation can be found in Fig. 4d. The spatial separation of copper and zinc oxide leads to an increased amount of Cu-Cu and ZnO-ZnO interactions. Therefore, the agglomeration may be accelerated when the finely dispersed copper nanoparticles are no longer surrounded by zinc oxide. Additional information in regard to the dispersion of the copper and ZnO nanoparticles can be obtained from TEM investigations. Representative TEM images are displayed in Fig. 5 and in the Supplementary Material in Fig. S5 and Fig. S6. Fig. 5a and e show the embedded copper nanoparticles mentioned in the previous paragraph. The copper crystals are between five and ten nanometers in size prior to the catalytic experiment. Single zinc oxide crystals are not visible. In agreement with these observations, the SAED shows only blurred zinc oxide and more recognizable copper reflections (Fig. 5c). After catalysis, the investigated agglomerate displays a similar behavior as already observed for a large number of particles in the SEM-EDX measurements, i.e. the occurrence of the spatial separation of copper and zinc oxide (Fig. 5b). In Fig. 5f and g are the two different species shown. EELS analysis confirmed that the crystals in Fig. 5f are ZnO and in Fig. 5g Cu (Supplementary Material, Fig. S7). As the XRPD results already suggested, an increase in crystal size occurs for both species, which is particularly surprising, since according to the Tamman rule (solid state compounds become reactive and mobile at 1/2 to 2/3 of their melting temperature) copper and zinc oxide should not be reactive at these low temperatures.[84,85] It is also interesting that the two systems seem to grow differently. Fig. 5b and g indicate that the individual copper crystals tend to fuse together. Therefore, these crystals are no longer spherical but rather oval (Fig. 5g). This sintering mechanism seems to be of Particle Migration and Coalescence (PMC) type, as predicted by Prieto et al. for Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts.[73] The sintering was even more pronounced for pure copper powder (Supplementary Material, Fig. S4). Therefore, it can be assumed that high pressures (100 bar) and temperatures of 170 °C are sufficient to agglomerate freely moving copper particles. With ZnO, on the other hand, Ostwald ripening may occur. For a suggestion on how the effect of Ostwald ripening occurs mechanistically, see Section 3.3. Some large crystals are surrounded by plenty of small ones (Fig. 5b and f) which allows the crystal sizes to be roughly divided into two classes. It is possible that Fig. 5 represents an intermediate stage in which the small crystals are not completely dissolved. The two different classes of crystal sizes for ZnO are also evident in the diffractogram of Fig. 5d. The majority of the diffraction rings of zinc oxide are similarly faded as in the catalyst before catalysis, suggesting small, differently oriented crystals. However, there are also a few intense reflections of zinc oxide, which indicate large crystals. The agglomerates contain ZnO crystals of both size classes, as indicated by the intensity distribution of the reflections along the diffraction rings. This pattern cannot be observed to the same extent for copper. This is also an indication that their sintering mechanisms are different from each other. To prevent the growth of Cu (which are embedded in the ZnO matrix) by maintaining the spatial separation between the copper crystals, the Ostwald ripening of the zinc oxide must be prevented. Therefore, it must first be clarified which compound leads to the sintering process during the catalysis, since this event cannot be carried out solely by thermal activation (according to Tammans rule). 3.3 Identifying the compound causing the deactivation Fig. 6 presents the diffractograms of the catalysts after different treatments. When comparing the catalysts stirred for 24 h in TEA (with low water content) and anhydrous TEA, it becomes evident that water leads to the deactivation of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 6 and the mean crystal sizes of ZnO and Cu are listed in Table S2 in the Supplementary Material). The sintering process is particularly well recognizable by the zinc oxide reflections in the 35-40° 2θ region. Less sintering is observed if dried TEA is used. A way to suppress the sintering effect even further can be exerted by adding CO to remove water from the catalyst surface by the water gas shift reaction ( 6 ). (6) CO + H 2 O ⇌ CO 2 + H 2 ( S ) Therefore, catalysis with CO and H2 as reactants can be carried out without sintering of the catalyst (Supplementary Material, Fig. S8). A comparison of the experiment in TEA with the one in water shows that it is not the combination of amine and water that leads to deactivation, but rather water alone. This fact explains why the catalyst in the DEA/TEA mixture showed only half of the activity after 24 h compared to the TEA experiment. For each mole of DEMA synthesized, two moles of water were formed according to reactions ( 1 ) and ( 5 ) and therefore the deactivation was accelerated. A possible step in the sintering mechanism would be the formation of zinc hydroxide. First, water is adsorbed onto the zinc oxide and then zinc hydroxide is formed (reaction ( 7 )). (7) ZnO + H 2 O ⇌ Zn ( O H ) 2 Zinc hydroxide has a melting point (Tm = 125 °C) of less than 170 °C and decomposes into ZnO and H2O. The slow formation of zinc oxide crystals from zinc hydroxide at low temperatures (<90 °C) has already been demonstrated by Nicholas et al.[86]. Since the sintering process leads to the formation of larger crystals and because of the possible existence of a transport mechanism by Zn(OH)2 for the ZnO, this sintering behavior can be interpreted as Ostwald ripening. 3.4 Preventing deactivation by using a suitable adsorbate Fig. 7 shows that the solvent has a significant effect whether the catalyst sinters during methanol synthesis or not. The dipole moment seems to be an important property of the solvent (Fig. 8 ). A competitive equilibrium would be established at the adsorption sites of the catalyst for the possible adsorbing molecules (e.g., water and solvent). Therefore, if the solvent interacts very strongly with the catalyst and covers the surface, water will be removed from the catalyst surface and less sintering will occur. Since no drastic sintering was observed with solvents having a higher dipole moment than water, it is reasonable to assume that the strength of the adsorbed molecule-catalyst interaction increases with increasing dipole moment of the adsorbed compound. Therefore, catalyst deactivation is not a direct consequence of CO2/H2 methanol synthesis, but occurs if water remains adsorbed on the catalyst for a certain period of time (Fig. 3). Consequently, deactivation can be reduced if enough molecules with a higher dipole moment than water are available to cover the catalyst surface. The interaction between solvent and catalyst is most likely electrostatic (e.g. Zn(+)-solvent(−), O(−) – solvent(+), where (+) and (−) represent the partial charges and – the interaction between catalyst and solvent). As the dipole moment increases, so does the charge separation within the solvent and this may explain the different degrees of sintering of the catalyst for different solvents (high dipole moment equals a strong adsorbate). CO2/H2-catalysis for Cu/ZnO based catalysts in alcohols[7,12–15,20,23], some amines[7,13,14], and paraffin oil[35] may therefore not work because of fast catalyst degradation. The decreased sintering of ZnO (Fig. 8) also results in small copper crystals (Fig. 7 and supplementary material Table S4). Adsorption of the solvent instead of water can be utilized to reduce deactivation, but it may cause other problems. If the adsorption strength becomes too high, the catalyst may be poisoned by the solvent. A possible slowed down MeOH formation in DEEA can also be seen in Fig. 8. Compared to the amines TEA, TPA, and TBA, the MeOH synthesis in DEEA is very slow although the catalyst is still intact. This behavior might indicate solvent poisoning, but the MeOH formation rate may also be slower because the Henry constants of CO2 and H2, and thus their concentrations in DEEA, are lower than those of TEA (Table 3 ). A similar behavior can be seen for EtOH in Table 3. The compounds with a higher dipole moment than water (ethylene glycol, DEEA, and propylene carbonate) have lower Henry constants than EtOH (representing the alcohols) and TEA (representing the amines) and therefore presumably a lower methanol yield. The alcohols may combine several positive influences for maximum, short-term MeOH output, such as delaying the sintering process due to a dipole moment similar to that of water (main difference to TEA) and high Henry constants (compared to ethylene glycol, DEEA and propylene carbonate). The high amount of MeOH formed therefore also results in a high water load for the catalyst, which may be the reason that the catalysts in the alcohols sintered the most after 24 h. Another explanation for the high yield in alcohols could be a different reaction mechanism as suggested by Tsubaki et al.[19,25]. Further investigations are required to address the potential poisoning of the catalyst by high dipole moment solvents. The varying water concentrations (corresponding to the amount of methanol synthesized in Table 3) hinder the comparability of the sintering rates of the catalyst in the different solvents. Therefore, sintering experiments were performed with the same water concentration (2 vol%) in the different solvents, being n-nonane, TEA, EtOH, ethylene glycol, and propylene carbonate. After two hours, the catalysts treated with the high dipole moment solvents (ethylene glycol and propylene carbonate) were not sintered by the water (supporting material Fig. S10). In the remaining cases, the catalyst sintered. The sintering of the catalyst in TEA was less severe than in n-nonane and EtOH which can be explained by the water removal according to reaction ( 4 ). Therefore, the observed phenomenon, that high dipole moment solvents are capable of hindering the sintering of the catalyst, is in good agreement with the results from the catalytic investigations. Another problem can be leaching in some solvents. In acetonitrile, the ZnO has been partly removed from the catalyst (Supplementary Material, Fig. S3). The subsequent increased interactions between the copper nanoparticles also led to a strong sintering of the copper, although no methanol (and therefore also no water) was formed. This observation also supports the assumption that zinc oxide is indispensable as a spacing unit for the copper nanocrystals. The catalysts after 24 h in Triglyme and PEG-400 also showed the appearance of foreign crystalline phases. They could not be assigned to known inorganic structures, so they are most likely organic degradation products of the solvent. Contamination of the catalyst and thus reduction of its active surface area is also undesirable and appears to be a problem when using ether-based solvents. Deactivation of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts in the gas phase process can also be caused by water.[4–6,80] To avoid this problem, it was proposed to stabilize the zinc oxide matrix in order to separate the copper crystals.[5] To test whether or not highly polar additives can interact with the catalyst from the gas phase, small amounts of solvent were introduced. Therefore, at the reaction temperature (200 °C), all components are gaseous (Fig. 9). The concentration for TEA, EtOH and ethylene glycol is 22.5 mM (equivalent to approximately 2 vol% in the gas phase under equilibrium conditions) and for propylene carbonate is 7.5 mM (0.7 vol%). Fig. 9 shows that the catalyst is highly sintered without any additives. As the dipole moment of the added gaseous solvent increases, the average size of the copper crystals decreases (for the same solvent concentrations). Therefore, it can be assumed that highly polar additives can interact with the catalyst from the gas phase and thus slow down the sintering process even at low concentrations. A concentration dependence can also be observed when comparing propylene carbonate and ethylene glycol. According to the mentioned equilibrium (water vs. solvent competing for adsorption sites on the catalyst), a lower solvent concentration may lead to a higher water concentration on the catalyst and consequently increase the sintering rate. Based on this behavior, it is also possible that using higher concentrations of the gaseous additive at industrial conditions (≈250 °C) could drastically slow down the sintering even further. However, some problems may occur. Most solvents are not stable under these conditions (Table 3), the interaction between the polar molecule and the catalyst could be so strong that poisoning occurs, and the separation of MeOH from the added solvent could be difficult and expensive. The most promising approach so far seems to use a mixture of an alcohol and a high dipole moment solvent (i.e. ethylene glycol or propylene carbonate). The alcohol could increase the methanol formation rate (Table 3) and the high dipole moment additive could decrease the sintering rate of the catalyst (Fig. 8). For the alcohol, methanol may be a suitable compound. Thrane et al. showed that small amounts of methanol in the feed gas resulted in an increased methanol yield in the gas phase process.[87] The use of methanol would also eliminate the need to separate the added alcohol from the product. 4 Conclusion The deactivation of the catalyst is due to the decreasing specific surface area of copper and zinc oxide with increasing reaction time. The reason for the change in the behavior of the catalyst can be attributed to the sintering process, leading to larger crystals of copper and zinc oxide. Various microscopic and diffraction techniques were used to better understand these phenomena. It has been shown that several processes occur, such as particle growth, mobilization of copper nanoparticles by dissolution of the ZnO matrix, separation of zinc and copper containing particles, and that different sintering mechanisms can be assigned to both components (ZnO: Ostwald ripening, Cu: PMC). To prevent the coalescence of copper nanoparticles, the initial zinc oxide structure must be maintained. Water has been identified as the cause of the sintering process. If the water is promptly removed from the catalyst surface, the catalyst remains intact. Taking advantage of this behavior, strongly adsorbing solvent molecules have been used to remove water from the catalyst and counteract the sintering process. The investigation clearly shows that there is a fundamental difference between the methanol synthesis from CO2 rich and syngas feeds in respect to catalyst degradation due to different degrees of water production. However, the results suggest a possible way to counteract the sintering propensity in CO2/H2 gas phase methanol synthesis on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts by adding small amounts of high dipole moment additives. The potential poisoning of the catalyst by the solvent and the occurrence of side reactions are issues that need to be addressed in further studies. coredata.dc:description: The sintering process on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts in the heterogeneous liquid phase assisted methanol synthesis from CO2/H2 was investigated. In order to better understand the sintering event, in addition to standard methods (XRD, XPS, BET, ICP-OES) microscopic techniques with different magnifications such as SEM-EDX, AFM, and TEM were used. Water has been identified as the sintering agent. In addition to eliminating water with CO, another way was found to remove water from the catalyst surface and therefore to counteract the sintering during catalysis. This goal can be achieved by using highly polar solvents allowing to synthesize MeOH solely from carbon dioxide and hydrogen, without deactivating the catalyst or using carbon monoxide.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by Elsevier Inc.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts by sintering in liquid phase assisted methanol synthesis from CO2/H2 and a way to counteract it
